Clients                  Request More Information     Apply to Wagner                                           Applying Knowledge in the Field   A requirement of the  Master of Public Administration and Master of Urban Planning  programs at NYU Wagner, Capstone provides students with both a critical learning experience and an opportunity to perform a public service. Over the course of an academic year, students in Capstone work in teams with faculty oversight to address challenges and identify opportunities for a client organization or to conduct research on a pressing social question.    Capstone projects require students to get up-to-speed quickly on a specific content or issue area; enhance key process skills such as project management and teamwork; and develop competency in gathering, analyzing, and reporting out on data. For students, it's an opportunity to interweave their learning in all these areas and to do so in real time, in an unpredictable, complex, real-world environment; for organizations, it's a chance to have current and future public service leaders focused on their success.   Join us for the 2015 Capstone Expo  Date: Tuesday, May 12, 2015  Time: 5:00pm-6:30pm / Reception to Follow from 6:30pm-7:30pm  Location: NYU Kimmel Center, Rosenthal Pavilion - 10th Floor  60 Washington Square South, New York, NY 10012  RSVP: here   Acknowledgement   Thank you to FJC: a Foundation of Philanthropic Funds for generous financial support of our Capstone program. Erin Longbothum   Restored Homes HDFC      Read more                      Erin Longbothum    Restored Homes HDFC , ' 13        The most exciting way I have been involved as an alumna is being the project liaison for a Capstone project this past year. My organization asked the students to come up with innovative solutions and alternative interventions to specific identified issues. I was able to take the students into the field and show them some of our work and how the project could complement the organization's ongoing work. The students that chose our project are really talented and thoughtful, and I am excited to see their research fully actualized.               The team delivered an outstanding presentation which was appreciated by nearly 100 local government practitioners from all over Africa.          World Bank Institute      Read more                         World Bank Institute, ' 13        The team delivered an outstanding presentation which was appreciated by nearly 100 local government practitioners from all over Africa.               This has been an unusually rewarding experience, in that it never seemed like a 'student project' and we felt that we benefited from our engagement with the team more than they did.          Governance Matters      Read more                         Governance Matters, ' 13        This has been an unusually rewarding experience, in that it never seemed like a 'student project' and we felt that we benefited from our engagement with the team more than they did. Their contributions to our projects are very substantial: they moved us forward and refined our approach, and were always gracious, collegial and thoughtful. We will be adopting all of their recommendations and templates.               The transformative, thoughtful, strategic work your students are doing to implement a new and more sophisticated evaluation and monitoring system for our nonprofit is way beyond our expectations. Each member of the team is brighter and more hard-working than the next.        Girl Be Heard        Read more                      Girl Be Heard    , '        The transformative, thoughtful, strategic work your students are doing to implement a new and more sophisticated evaluation and monitoring system for our nonprofit is way beyond our expectations. Each member of the team is brighter and more hard-working than the next. What is most remarkable is that each student has a very unique set of skills that complements the group. I hardly have a moment to breathe, most days, but look forward to meetings with our Capstone team since our dialogues are focused, engaging and eye-opening. I trust their work process, intellect and vision. Thank you for allowing us the opportunity to work with such a crackerjack team.               The Capstone team filled in a critical missing piece of our work and did it with dedication, enthusiasm, patience, as well as cross-cultural awareness and understanding.          Paula Shirk   Brooklyn Bridge to Cambodia      Read more                      Paula Shirk    Brooklyn Bridge to Cambodia, '        The Capstone team filled in a critical missing piece of our work and did it with dedication, enthusiasm, patience, as well as cross-cultural awareness and understanding. One of the BB2C guests turned to me at the final presentation and remarked that it 'renews my faith in the future of America when I see what these young people are accomplishing.'                 The students created sets of maps for hundreds of our directly administered, affiliated and sponsored agencies and sites, and then further mapped these site locations onto various NYS boundaries.          Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York      Read more                         Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, ' 13        The students created sets of maps for hundreds of our directly administered, affiliated and sponsored agencies and sites, and then further mapped these site locations onto various NYS boundaries. The Capstone Team was phenomenal. They presented their final work to our agency's Senior Management, and we were blown away. We have been trying to do this project for years, and the students were able to facilitate the process in a few months. Kudos and thanks to the Capstone management and to the Wagner School. I hardly have a moment to breathe, most days, but look forward to meetings with our Capstone team since our dialogues are focused, engaging and eye-opening. I trust their work process, intellect and vision. Thank you for allowing us the opportunity to work with such a crackerjack team.                 As a former student, I found the Capstone project to be one of the highlights of the Wagner program both personally and professionally.        Johanna Simon   Malaria No More      Read more                      Johanna Simon    Malaria No More, ' 13        As a former student, I found the Capstone project to be one of the highlights of the Wagner program both personally and professionally. And now, as a Capstone client with Malaria No More, I am able to see firsthand the tremendous impact of the students’ work. Wagner students recently completed a research study in Cameroon investigating the knowledge and practices of fever treatment, which we are using to inform our malaria education and communication efforts in the country. The students’ dedication to the project not only made for a good working experience, but also ensured the quality of their work.               Our Capstone team has been stunningly professional and effective in every way throughout the past nine months.          The Mountain Institute      Read more                         The Mountain Institute, ' 13        Our Capstone team has been stunningly professional and effective in every way throughout the past nine months. They have given us training, tools and passion to enable us to transform our ability to think and communicate about ourselves and our work. As a result of their project, we can market our important work in mountain communities and environments around the world far, far more effectively. Their final presentation was a ‘ninth inning World Series grand slam.               The final presentation was a tour de force! Thank you for providing us with the opportunity to collaborate with NYU.          Rye WMCA      Read more                         Rye WMCA, ' 13        The final presentation was a tour de force! Thank you for providing us with the opportunity to collaborate with NYU. We deeply appreciate the resources and experience provided by the Capstone team, who were all wonderful to work with – smart, bright, enthusiastic. The project offers you the chance to work with a startup company or nonprofit organization and propose a solution to a real business need. Each year, the program partners with nonprofit organizations to design student projects that not only advance your business acumen and technological skills, but also further your commitment to social responsibility. Examples of recent student projects include:     The development and implementation of a customer service component for an online retailer   The implementation of a project management program office   The development and implementation of medical records digitization and retrieval system   The design and implementation of a management dashboard for a real estate development firm   The application of traditional business practices to small nonprofits               The Thesis Project   You may elect to work on a thesis research project in lieu of the applied project. The thesis provides an opportunity to make a unique contribution to the body of knowledge in a subject area studied in the M.S. in Management and Systems program. Working under the mentorship of a faculty supervisor, students select a topic; develop a research model; conduct research and analysis; and write a significant thesis paper to be reviewed by experts in the field. Examples of recent student theses include:     An Exploration into the Universal Standardization of Electronic Medical Records in Hospitals that Are Striving for Interoperability   Collaboration Technologies and Virtual Teams: A Study of the Effectiveness of Collaboration Technologies in a Distance Learning Setting   Women and Mentorship: Mentorship Relationships Involving Women in the Finance Industry During the 2007-2009 Recession   A Study of the Relationship Between Potential Influential Factors and Consumer’s Attitudes Toward Mobile Instant Messaging Services   Content Credibility in Social Media                                                                                                                                        QUICK LINKS                        About Us          Student Affairs          Visit Us          School-wide Policies          Contact Us                       ATTEND THE SCHOOL                        Graduate Admissions          Undergraduate Admissions          Noncredit Registration          Veteran Resource Center                             ON THE WEB                         On Facebook          On Twitter          On YouTube          Browser Requirements                                                        NYU Homepage    © New York University School of Professional Studies | Privacy Policy

The project offers you the chance to work with a startup company or nonprofit organization and propose a solution to a real business need. Each year, the program partners with nonprofit organizations to design student projects that not only advance your business acumen and technological skills, but also further your commitment to social responsibility. Examples of recent student projects include:     The development and implementation of a customer service component for an online retailer   The implementation of a project management program office   The development and implementation of medical records digitization and retrieval system   The design and implementation of a management dashboard for a real estate development firm   The application of traditional business practices to small nonprofits               The Thesis Project   You may elect to work on a thesis research project in lieu of the applied project. The thesis provides an opportunity to make a unique contribution to the body of knowledge in a subject area studied in the M.S. in Management and Systems program. Working under the mentorship of a faculty supervisor, students select a topic; develop a research model; conduct research and analysis; and write a significant thesis paper to be reviewed by experts in the field.                                          Graduation Requirements                                               Capstone Project                                                          Capstone Project                                                               During the fourth year, every NYUAD student will produce a Capstone Project, which may be either an individual or team project. Students do a Capstone Project in their major field. The Capstone Project is a demanding, year-long endeavor aiming at a significant piece of research or creative work—an historical narrative, musical composition, performance, invention, documented experiment, scholarly thesis, or other form appropriate to the student’s goals. Unlike other courses in which faculty establish the structure and set assignments, the Capstone Project puts the student in charge. The fundamental challenge is to enter unmapped terrain and to extend oneself in making knowledge, reframing conventional approaches to an issue or creating something new.     No matter what form the Capstone takes, each student will have a faculty mentor and participate in a Capstone seminar that serves as a forum to discuss the research process and present work in progress. These seminars offer a model of intellectual community and collaborative learning in which participants offer their thoughts across fields of study and engage in active critique and revision. At the end of the school year, the students will present their Capstone work at a university-wide celebration of their creative achievements.
